abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First Programmatic
            Development Policy Grant Operation Project (PDPG) for
            Tajikistan were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the
            risk to development outcome was moderate, the Bank
            performance was moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was also moderately satisfactory. Ratings for
            the Second Programmatic Development Policy Grant Operation
            Project for Tajikistan were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was moderately satisfactory. Ratings for the
            Third Programmatic Development Policy Grant Operation
            Project for Tajikistan were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: achieving development results is possible if
            interventions are designed on the basis of a good
            understanding of Tajikistan's political economy and the
            Bank is willing to be flexible in identifying the reform
            program that it will support. Having in place a good
            monitoring and evaluation framework promotes a better
            dialogue improves government coordination and helps in
            monitoring implementation and progress towards expected
            outcomes. A mix of development policy lending and investment
            operations can be effective in supporting development
            outcomes in post-conflict and fragile states. However, the
            desire to improve overall portfolio performance carries the
            risk of overloading the policy-based finance agenda.
            Providing support for implementation of the reform agenda is
            essential to success in environments of low capacity. Basing
            the reform program on a strong foundation of analytical work
            and piloting innovative approaches can help stakeholders
            better understand what will work in the specific
            circumstances of Tajikistan. Substantial progress has made
            with development partner coordination, with the Bank
            regularly consulting with other development partners on a
            wide variety of issues. This has led to a greater division
            of labor among partners and reduced and the burden on
            government of uncoordinated development partner efforts. The
            International Monetary Fund (IMF), the Asian Development
            Bank, the European Commission (EC), and the major bilateral
            donors in Tajikistan were all informed of the status of the
            implementation of the prior actions and milestones of the
            PDPG 1-3 series to ensure that all were able to advance the
            reform agenda.
